September 29, 2013: Fiction
W IS FOR WASTED, by Sue Grafton. (Marian Wood/Putnam.) A homeless man
inexplicably leaves $600,000 to Kinsey Millhone.
NEVER GO BACK, by Lee Child. (Delacorte.) Jack Reacher is thrown into jail on
trumped-up charges.
THE CUCKOO'S CALLING, by Robert Galbraith. (Mullholland Books/Little,
Brown.) A detective investigates a suicide; by J.K. Rowling, writing
pseudonymously.
THE MAYAN SECRETS, by Clive Cussler and Thomas Perry. (Putnam.) Sam and
Remi Fargo, a husband-and-wife treasure-hunting team, discover a Mayan codex.
INFERNO, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday.) The symbologist Robert Langdon, on the
run in Florence, must decipher a series of codes created by a Dante-loving
scientist.
ROBERT B. PARKER'S DAMNED IF YOU DO, by Michael Brandman. (Putnam.)
A continuation of Parker’s series featuring Jesse Stone, the chief of police in
Paradise, Mass.
SECOND WATCH, by J. A. Jance. (Morrow/HarperCollins.) The investigator J. P.
Beaumont has disturbing dreams about his early days on the Seattle P.D. and his
time in Vietnam.
AND THE MOUNTAINS ECHOED, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead.) A
multigenerational family saga centers on a brother and sister born in Afghanistan.
SOMEONE, by Alice McDermott. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux.) Looking back on the
life of an ordinary woman.
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown.) A woman disappears on her fifth
anniversary; is her husband a killer?
SONGS OF WILLOW FROST, by Jamie Ford. (Ballantine.) A 12-year-old Seattle
orphan during the Depression becomes convinced that a movie star is really his
vanished mother.
THE HUSBAND'S SECRET, by Liane Moriarty. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam.) A
woman’s life is upended when she discovers a letter she was not meant to read.
MISTRESS, by James Patterson and David Ellis. (Little, Brown.) A man discovers
that his friend led a double life.
HOW THE LIGHT GETS IN, by Louise Penny. (Minotaur.) Chief Inspector Armand
Gamache of the Sûreté du Québec seeks a refuge in the tiny mountain village of
Three Pines.
September 29, 2013
Non-Fiction
SI-COLOGY 1, by Si Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard Books.) Tales
from Phil’s youngest brother, retired from the Army, works in the Duck
Commander workshop.
STILL FOOLIN' 'EM, by Billy Crystal. (Holt.) The 65-year-old comedian’s
reminiscences and his complaints about aging.
THE LIBERTY AMENDMENTS, by Mark R. Levin. (Threshold Editions.) The talk-
radio host offers 11 proposals for returning to America's founding principles.
EMPTY MANSIONS, by Bill Dedman and Paul Clark Newell Jr.. (Ballantine.) The
eccentric life of the reclusive heiress Huguette Clark, who died at the age of 104 in
ZEALOT, by Reza Aslan. (Random House.) A biography of Jesus of Nazareth
presents him in the context of his times as the leader of a revolutionary movement.
LEAN IN, by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf.) The chief operating
officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.
HAPPY, HAPPY, HAPPY, by Phil Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard
Books.) The Duck Commander pays tribute to “faith, family and ducks.”
WILSON, by A. Scott Berg. (Putnam.) A new biography of the 28th president.
NOTHIN' TO LOSE, by Ken Sharp with Paul Stanley and Gene Simmons. (It
Books.) An oral history of the early years (1972-5) of the band Kiss.
LAWRENCE IN ARABIA, by Scott Anderson. (Doubleday.) A history of the Arab
revolt against the Turks in World War I focuses on T.E. Lawrence and other
adventurers.
FIVE DAYS AT MEMORIAL, by Sheri Fink. (Crown.) The case of a New Orleans
surgeon suspected of euthanizing patients during the Katrina disaster.
A HOUSE IN THE SKY, by Amanda Lindhout and Sara Corbett. (Scribner.) A
memoir of a young woman’s brutal kidnapping and 460-day captivity in Somalia.
THIS TOWN, by Mark Leibovich. (Blue Rider.) An examination of Washington’s
“media-industrial complex” by the chief national correspondent for The Times
Magazine.
SALINGER, by David Shields and Shane Salerno. (Simon & Schuster.) An oral
history of the writer, a companion volume to the recently released documentary.
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House.) An Olympic runner’s story
of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II after his plane went down
